journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Effect of siloxane treatment of jute fabric on the mechanical and thermal properties of jute/HDPE

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Chemistry, Dokuz Eylul University, Buca, Izmir, Turkey
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, Ege University, Bornova, Izmir, Turkey
3Department of Mechanical Engineering, Dokuz Eylul University, Bornova, Izmir, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: Yoldaş Seki, Department of Chemistry, Dokuz Eylul University, Buca, Izmir, Turkey Email: yoldas.seki@deu.edu.tr

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The mechanical and thermal properties of jute fiber/HDPE composites as a function of alkali and oligomeric siloxane treatment of jute fabric were investigated. The effect of surface treatments on the composites was assessed by means of tensile test, short-beam shear test, three-point bending test, SEM, TGA, and DSC. When jute fabric are first treated with alkali solution and then oligomeric siloxane solution, 34% and 49% increases in tensile and flexural strength were observed, respectively. Moreover, it is interesting to note that after alkali and siloxane treatment of jute fabric, 169% increase in ILSS of jute/HDPE composite was obtained. This demonstrates that the adhesion between jute fiber and HDPE matrix is greatly increased by alkali and oligomeric siloxane treatment of jute fabric. This observation was also confirmed by SEM analysis of fracture surface of composites. Alkali and oligomeric siloxane treatment of jute fabric did not considerably change thermal stability and melting and crystallization temperatures of jute/HDPE.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: During last decade, many research activities have been dedicated to natural fiber-reinforced thermoplastic composites.1–10 Especially polypropylene (PP) matrix composites are gaining increasing interest. Polyethylene, like PP, belongs to the class of inexpensive commodity thermoplastics and is worth testing as a matrix material.11 Polyethylene is one of the most extensively used thermoplastics due to its advantages in regard to economy (price) and ecology (recycling behavior).

Natural fibers like banana, cotton, coir, sisal, and jute have attracted the attention of scientists and technologists for applications in consumer goods, low-cost housing, and other civil structures.3 Natural fibers exhibit many advantageous properties for use as reinforcement materials for composites. They are low-density materials yielding considerably lightweight composites with highly specific properties. Natural fibers also offer significant cost advantages and benefits associated with their processing, relative to synthetic fibers. Also, they are a highly renewable resource, which reduces the dependency on petroleum oil.12,13

Jute was used to produce composite materials with different matrices such as semicrystalline copolyester,14 PP,15 l-polylactide,16 poly(butylene succinate,17 polycarbonate,18 polyethylene,19 methylmethacrylate,20 polycaprolactone,21 etc. Since jute has higher strength and modulus than plastic22 and is a good substitute for conventional fibers in many applications.13 However, being hydrophilic, jute fibers do not adhere well to the hydrophobic polymer matrix and absorb water from surrounding media or moisture.10 Therefore, enhancement of adhesion between jute fiber and one of the thermoplastic matrices, high-density polyethylene (HDPE), is necessary. Enhanced interfacial adhesion in composites containing jute fibers can be achieved by chemical/physical treatments of the fiber or matrix as well as by the use of interfacial additives.23,24 Chemical treatments including alkali, silane, acetylation, and isocyanides can increase the interface adhesion between the fiber and matrix, and decrease the water absorption of fibers.25 Raw jute fiber composites were post treated with maleic acid to increase the compatibility of the jute fiber with the PP matrix by Rahman et al.11 Recently, silane coupling agents were also found to be effective in modifying natural fiber–polymer matrix composites, increasing the interfacial strength.26,27 Bifunctional silane molecules act as links between the resin and the cellulose by forming chemical bonds.24 Oligomeric siloxane (OS; Z-6173) has alkoxy and alkyl functional groups and may be considered as dispersing agent.25 Alkyl functionality is compatible with organic polymer matrices.28

In this study, in order to improve adhesion, modification of jute fabric surface with an OS was performed. The effect of this modification on mechanical and thermal properties of jute/HDPE composites was investigated.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Jute fabric, which is of areal mass 300 g/m2, were purchased from Anil Limited, Turkey. OS was supplied from Dow Corning under the commercial name of Z-6173. HDPE (S0452, 0.950–0.956 g/cm3) was obtained from PETKIM Petrokimya Holding A.S. HDPE was utilized in pellet form with melt flow index value of 0.30–0.50 g/10 min.

sec.title: Surface treatments
sec.p: Jute fabrics were treated with an aqueous solution of NaOH (2% w/w) for 2 h. The fabrics were then neutralized with acetic acid solution and then washed many times in fresh distilled water until all the sodium hydroxide was eliminated. Finally, all treated fabrics were dried at room temperature for 48 h.

OS was dissolved in alcohol solution (96%) at a level of 1% by weight of jute fabric. The solution was sonicated in ultrasonic bath for 5 min to have homogenous solution. The alkalized jute fabrics were immersed in siloxane solution for 60 min. Next, the fibers were washed and kept in oven at 65°C for 2 h.

sec.title: Composite manufacturing
sec.p: Thermoplastic composites were fabricated by the compression molding technique. This process was carried out by using a hot-press. The hydraulic molding press has a maximum load capacity of 600 kN.

The HDPE granules were compression molded at 195°C into 1-mm-thick isotropic sheets. The compressive pressure of 120 bar was maintained during cooling to ambient temperature. Composite laminates, which are in-plane dimensions of 250–350 mm, were fabricated by placing jute fabrics (20%wt) between HDPE thermoplastic sheets. Then, the sheets were heated to 195°C for 15 min and compression molded under a pressure of 120 bar. Afterwards, laminate was slowly cooled to ambient temperature.

sec.title: Tensile test
sec.p: Tensile tests were carried out on a Shimadzu AUTOGRAPH AG-G Series universal testing machine equipped with a 5000 N load cell, according to ASTM D-3039. The cross-head speed used for the tensile specimens was 2 mm/min. System control and data analysis were preformed using Trapezium software (advanced software for materials testing). At least five specimens, which were 165-mm long, 25-mm wide, and 3-mm thick, were tested for each type of composite sheet to check for repeatability.

sec.title: Short-beam shear test
sec.p: Short-beam shear tests were carried out according to ASTM D-2344. A sliding roller three-point bending fixture, which included a loading pin (diameter 6.4 mm) and two support pins (diameter 3.2 mm), was mounted in a 5-kN capacity, screw-driven load frame. Shimadzu AUTOGRAPH AG-G Series universal testing machine was used with a cross-head speed of 1.3 mm/min. The tests were carried out at six times for each type of composite sheet. The length and width of the test specimens were 26.3 and 6.4 mm, respectively. The apparent interlaminar shear strength (ILSS) of composites was determined from specimens that were tested with a support span/sample thickness ratio of 5:1.

sec.title: Three-point bending test
sec.p: The flexural strength and modulus of the composites were measured using a three-point bending test according to ASTM D 790. The three-point bend fixture, manufactured by Shimadzu, was used in a universal test machine running in a three-point bending mode. The tests were carried out with a span-to-depth ratio of 16:1 at a cross-head speed of 1.3 mm/min. Test specimens with length of 80 mm and width of 25 mm were prepared using a diamond cutter. At least six samples were measured and the results were averaged.

sec.title: Scanning electron microscopy observation
sec.p: By means of this observation, it was possible to qualitatively determine adhesion degree between the matrix and reinforcement. The tensile fracture surfaces of the composites were observed using a scanning electron microscope (JEOL JSM 6060) at accelerating voltage equal to 5 kV in the secondary electron mode. The fracture surfaces of the composite samples were coated with gold by means of a plasma sputtering apparatus prior to scanning electron microscopy (SEM) observation.

sec.title: Thermogravimetric analysis
sec.p: The thermal stability of the composite samples was evaluated by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) using Diamond TGA/DTA Perkin Elmer Model equipment. Samples of 10 mg weight were scanned from 30°C to 600°C at a heating rate of 10°C/min under nitrogen flow of 150 mL/min.

sec.title: Differential scanning calorimetry
sec.p: Melting and crystallization behaviors of samples were investigated using differential scanning calorimetry (Diamond DSC Perkin Elmer). DSC analyses were operated in a dynamic mode under nitrogen atmosphere. Samples between 5 and 10 mg were placed in an aluminum pan and sealed. The samples were scanned from 0°C to 250°C at the heating rate of 10°C. Then, the samples were held for 2 min at 250°C. After cooling process from 250°C to 0°C at 10°C/min, specimens were held for 2 min at 0°C. Again, a second heating process from 0 to 250°C at 10°C/min was performed. The degree of crystallinity was obtained from melting heat of fusion data.

sec.title: Tensile test
sec.p:
Tensile properties of jute/HDPE (J/HDPE) composites are summarized in Table 1. Tensile strength, tensile modulus, and strain at break values for virgin HDPE are 23.31 MPa, 0.57 GPa, and 850%, respectively. Tensile strength values are 21.2, 24.9, and 29.1 MPa for J/HDPE, alkalized jute/HDPE (AJ/HDPE), and OS-treated jute /HDPE (OSJ/HDPE) composites, respectively. Alkali treatment of jute fabric causes 17% increase in tensile strength of jute/HDPE composites. OS treatment of alkalized jute fabric resulted in 17% enhancement in tensile strength. Moreover, it can be said that when jute fabric are first treated with alkali solution and then OS, a 34% increase in tensile strength was obtained. It is believed that this alkali treatment results in an improvement in the interfacial bonding by giving rise to additional sites of mechanical interlocking, hence promoting more resin/fiber interpenetration at the interface. OS behaves as a coupling agent and promotes the adhesion by creating a hydrophobic surface. Thus, hydrophobic interactions occur in the fiber–matrix interface. Due to a good adhesion between OS-treated jute and HDPE, it is possible to transfer the load from fiber to matrix. The variations in values of tensile modulus for the composites are presented in Table 1. As shown here, tensile moduli are 1.21, 1.42, and 1.47 GPa for J/HDPE, AJ/HDPE, and OSJ/HDPE, respectively. Table 1.
Mechanical properties of the jute/HDPE composites
Samples Fiber loading (%) Tensile strength (MPa) Tensile modulus (GPa) Strain at break (%) Flexural strength (MPa) Flexural modulus (GPa) ILSS (MPa)
J/HDPE 20 21.2 ± 0.7 1.21 ± 0.09 4.8 ± 0.3 31.4 ± 0.9 0.84 ± 0.07 5.8 ± 0.4
AJ/HDPE 20 24.9 ± 0.7 1.42 ± 0.09 5.5 ± 0.4 38.1 ± 1.1 1.02 ± 0.07 7.1 ± 0.4
OSJ/HDPE 20 29.1 ± 0.7 1.47 ± 0.01 10.3 ± 0.6 46.8 ± 2.2 1.67 ± 0.15 15.6 ± 1.0

sec.title: Short-beam shear test
sec.p: ILSS of J/HDPE, AJ/HDPE, and OSJ/HDPE composites are given in Table 1. The ILSS of laminates was obtained using the short-beam method. The ILSS values were determined to be 5.8, 7.1, and 15.6 MPa for J/HDPE, AJ/HDPE, and OSJ/HDPE composites, respectively. The ILSS markedly increased by alkali and OS treatment. Alkali treatment caused 25% increase in the ILSS of jute/HDPE. It is interesting to note that OS treatment of jute fabric caused 120% increase in the ILSS of alkalized jute/HDPE composite. OS containing alkoxy- and alkyl-functional groups acts as a hydrophobing agent. The alkyl functionality acts both as a compatibilizer with organic polymer matrices and a hydrophobe to reduce water absorption. The increment in ILSS values of jute/HDPE composites demonstrates that the adhesion at the interface between fiber and matrix is greatly increased.

sec.title: Three-point bending test
sec.p: The flexural properties (flexure strength and flexure modulus) are given in Table 1. As can be seen from Table 1, the alkali and OS treatment of jute fabric showed a tendency to increase the flexural strength and the flexural modulus of jute/HDPE composite. The alkalization processes of jute fabric enhanced the flexural strength of the jute/HDPE composite from 31.4 to 38.1 MPa. It can be seen that the flexural strength of the AJ/HDPE composite was 21.3% higher and the modulus of elasticity was 21.9% higher as compared with those of the J/HDPE composite. The treatment of the vegetable fibers with a diluted alkaline solution promotes the partial removal of the hemicelluloses, waxes, and lignin present on the surface of the fiber and leads to some changes in their morphology and chemical composition.29,30 The removal of hemicelluloses, waxes, and lignin from the fiber surface enhances the surface roughness. Alkali treatment leads to the formation of a rough surface, which would increase the mechanical interlocking between the fiber and the matrix.31 It can be said that the nature of the bonding between the fiber and HDPE is mainly mechanical interlocking with little chemical bonding. The flexural strength values were measured to be 46.8 MPa for OSJ/HDPE composite. Application of OS treatment on alkalized jute fabric resulted in an increase in terms of flexural strength and flexural modulus. The flexural strength of OSJ/HDPE composite was 22.8% higher and the modulus of elasticity was 64.4% higher compared with those of AJ/HDPE composite.

Aji et al.32 worked on tensile and flexural properties of hybridized kenaf/pineapple leaf fiber-reinforced HDPE composite. At 0.25 mm fiber length, tensile strength of 32.24 MPa, flexural strength and modulus of 34.01 and 4114.11 MPa, respectively, were observed at 60% fiber loading.32 When these findings were compared with the results in this study, it is seen that OSJ/HDPE composites exhibit almost similar tensile strength, greater flexural strength, and lower flexural modulus. Mohanty et al. studied the effect of fiber loading on mechanical strength of jute/HDPE composites. They obtained that the greatest tensile (27.24 MPa) and flexural strength (34.83 MPa) was obtained with the fiber loading of 30%.33 These values are also lower than those of OSJ/HDPE composite in our study.

sec.title: SEM analysis
sec.p:
The fracture surfaces of the specimens were investigated by SEM observations. Figure 1 shows the SEM micrograph of J/HDPE composites. As can be seen from Figure 1(a), the fiber surfaces are free from any adhering polymer. Matrix material does not firmly stick onto the fiber surface. Clean fiber surfaces indicate extensive interfacial failure which shows poor fiber/matrix adhesion. It offers an adhesive failure in the interface. Besides, interface structure cannot transfer stress effectively. As can be seen from SEM micrograph of AJ/HPDE composite, there are some fiber groups which are held together by matrix material in these groups. It can be said that matrix material sticks relatively better to the fiber surface. The differences between the failure surfaces of J/HDPE and AJ/HDPE specimens can be realized from Figure 1(a) and (b). As depicted in SEM micrograph of OSJ/HDPE composites (Figure 1(c)), it can be said that matrix material firmly sticks to the modified jute fiber. Thus, the fibers are held together. Considering SEM micrograph of J/HDPE, it can be said that modification of fiber surface with OS resulted in good interfacial adhesion between the fibers and matrix. Interface structure can transfer stress effectively from fiber to matrix material. Figure 1.
SEM images of the breakage regions for (a) J/HDPE, (b) AJ/HDPE, and (c) OSJ/HDPE.

sec.title: TGA analysis
sec.p:
In order to determine whether alkali and OS treatment of jute fabric alter thermal properties of jute/HDPE composites, it is necessary to conduct TGA and DSC analyses. The TGA and DTG curves of J/HDPE, AJ/HDPE, and OSJ/HDPE composites are presented in Figures 2 and 3, respectively. TGA results of composites are summarized in Table 2. Degradation temperature and mass loss for virgin HDPE are 473°C and 80.1%, respectively. For the J/HDPE composite, the first peak was observed between 265°C and 383°C with a maximum at 356°C, which corresponds to a weight loss of about 10.7%. It may be attributed to dehydration of cellulose unit of jute and thermal cleavage of glycosidic linkage by transglycosylation and scission of C–O and C–C bonds, i.e., the thermal depolymerization of hemicellulose and the glycosidic linkages of cellulose.33,34 The second decomposition came about between 400°C and 509°C with a maximum at 478°C, as seen from DTG curves. The mass loss in this main decomposition step was about 84%. This main decomposition step may be due to aromatization, involving dehydration reactions.33,35 At 510°C, the weight of the charred residue left was about 6.0%. Similar results have also obtained by Mohanty et al.33 AJ/HDPE and OSJ/HDPE composites demonstrate a peak at 361°C and 362°C due to dehydration from the cellulose unit and thermal cleavage and scission of C–O and C–C bonds. These maximum decomposition temperatures are comparatively higher than those of J/HDPE composite. The mass loss at this first stage for AJ/HDPE and OSJ/HDPE was obtained to be 9.6% (270–390°C) and 9.7% (280–388°C), respectively. The second decomposition temperatures of AJ/HDPE and OSJ/HDPE were obtained in the temperature range 390–509°C with maxima at 478°C and 477°C, respectively. This decomposition step for AJ/HDPE and OSJ/HDPE is almost the same as that of J/HDPE. The mass of the charred residue left at 509°C was about 5.4% and 5.9%, for AJ/HDPE and OSJ/HDPE, respectively. OS treatment of jute fabric does not alter the main decomposition temperature of J/HDPE composite. Figure 2.
TGA of fabricated composites. Figure 3.
DTG of fabricated composites. Table 2.
TGA results of composites
Samples T1 (°C) T2 (°C) Mass loss (%)
J/HDPE 356 478 94
AJ/HDPE 361 478 95
OSJ/HDPE 362 477 94

sec.title: DSC analysis
sec.p:
The variations of thermal properties of J/HDPE, AJ/HDPE, and OSJ/HDPE are given in Table 3. The melting point and enthalpy and crystallization temperature and enthalpy values for virgin HDPE are 137°C, 231 J/g, 117°C, and −193 J/g, respectively. The melting point of J/HDPE was detected as 130°C for heating process. Crystallization temperature of J/HDPE was determined to be 115°C. Alkalization and OS treatment of jute fabric did not almost change melting and crystallization temperature of J/HDPE. After OS treatment of jute fabric, the melting enthalpy of J/HDPE decreased from 139 to 125 J/g, respectively. The greater variation in crystallization enthalpy of jute/HDPE was noticed after alkali treatment of jute fabric. The degree of crystallinity Xc was calculated by the following equation:
where ΔHm is the melting point of composites (from second heating) obtained from DSC analysis and ΔH* the melting point of 100% cystalline HDPE. According to the literature, ΔH* of 100% crystalline of HDPE is taken to be 293 J/g.36 Table 3.
The variations of thermal properties of jute/HDPE composites
Samples Heating Cooling Xc (%)
Peak (°C) ΔHm (J/g) Peak (°C) ΔHc (J/g)
J/HDPE 130 139 115 −132 47.4
AJ/HDPE 130 135 115 −126 46.1
OSJ/HDPE 131 125 115 −133 42.7

The percentages of crystallinity for the composites are depicted in Table 3. Considering Xc, OS treatment of jute fabric led to considerable decrease in the percentage of crystallinity of jute/HDPE composite.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In the event that jute fabrics are first treated with alkali solution and then OS, 34% and 169% increases in tensile strength and ILSS of jute/HDPE composite were obtained, respectively. The increment in ILSS values of jute/HDPE composite demonstrates that the adhesion at the interface between fiber and matrix is greatly increased by alkali and subsequently OS treatment. These treatments also resulted in an increase in flexural strength and flexural modulus. The flexural strength of OS-treated jute/HDPE composite was 22.8% higher and the modulus of elasticity was 64.4% higher compared with those of alkalized jute/HDPE composite. OS treatment of jute fabric caused considerable decrease in the percentage of crystallinity of jute/HDPE composite. Thermal stability and melting and crystallization temperatures of J/HDPE do not differ so much from those of AJ/HDPE and OSJ/HDPE. It can be said that OS behaves as a coupling agent and promotes the adhesion by creating a hydrophobic surface between jute fiber and HDPE.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
